recipes.name: Macadamia Butter Chocolate Chip Cookies
ingredients: ½ cup shredded coconut (or almond meal)
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.

Step 2: Grind the macadamia nuts in a food processor or high-powered blender until they resemble coarse meal. Add the macadamia (or avocado) oil and continue to process until the mixture is smooth and resembles butter.
Step 3: Transfer the macadamia butter to a bowl. Add the erythritol, shredded coconut (or almond meal), egg, vanilla extract, and salt.
Step 4: Mix well until the dough comes together. Stir in the sugar-free chocolate chips.
Step 5: Shape the dough into 1-inch balls. Flatten each ball with the palm of your hand to about ¼-inch thickness.
Step 6: Bake for 10-12 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the edges are golden brown and the tops are beginning to set.
Step 7: Remove from oven and let the cookies cool completely on the baking sheet before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three macadamia butter chocolate chip cookies on a rustic wooden board, with scattered macadamia nuts and chocolate chips around.  Use warm, natural light from the side to highlight the cookie's golden edges and melty chocolate.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the center cookie's texture.  Incorporate a linen napkin subtly in the background for a touch of elegance.  Aim for a cozy, inviting mood with rich browns and creamy whites.  A slightly overhead angle showcasing the cookie's height and texture is desired.

video_script.title: Macadamia Butter Chocolate Chip Cookies
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and healthy macadamia butter chocolate chip cookies with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of several golden-brown macadamia butter chocolate chip cookies on a cooling rack, with a few macadamia nuts scattered around.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in the rich, nutty flavor of these healthy macadamia butter chocolate chip cookies. They're easy to make and perfect for satisfying your sweet cravings.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients laid out on a table: 1 cup raw macadamia nuts, 1 tablespoon macadamia oil (or avocado oil) in a small glass bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need. One cup of raw macadamia nuts and one tablespoon of macadamia oil, or avocado oil as a substitute.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients in separate bowls: ½ cup granulated erythritol, ½ cup shredded coconut (or almond meal) in a small bowl, 1 large egg in another small bowl, ½ teaspoon vanilla extract in a tiny bowl, ¼ teaspoon salt in a tiny bowl, and ⅓ cup sugar-free chocolate chips in a small bowl.
scenes.voice_over: You'll also need one-half cup of granulated erythritol, one-half cup of shredded coconut, or almond meal, one large egg, one-half teaspoon of vanilla extract, one-quarter teaspoon of salt, and two-thirds of a cup of sugar-free chocolate chips.

scenes.image_prompt: Macadamia nuts being ground in a food processor.
scenes.voice_over: First, preheat your oven to 325°F or 160°C and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Then, grind the macadamia nuts in a food processor until they become a coarse meal.

scenes.image_prompt: Macadamia butter being made in a food processor with added oil.
scenes.voice_over: Add the macadamia or avocado oil and continue processing until the mixture is smooth and resembles butter. This is your macadamia butter.

scenes.image_prompt: Mixing bowl with macadamia butter, erythritol, shredded coconut, egg, vanilla extract, and salt.
scenes.voice_over: Transfer the macadamia butter to a mixing bowl and add the erythritol, shredded coconut or almond meal, egg, vanilla extract, and salt. Mix thoroughly until the dough comes together.

scenes.image_prompt: Folding in chocolate chips into the dough.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the sugar-free chocolate chips, ensuring they're evenly distributed throughout the dough.

scenes.image_prompt: Shaping cookie dough into balls and flattening them on a baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Shape the dough into one-inch balls and flatten each to about a quarter-inch thickness on the prepared baking sheet.

scenes.image_prompt: Cookies baking in the oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown and the tops begin to set.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of golden-brown, perfectly baked macadamia butter chocolate chip cookies on a cooling rack with a glass of almond milk.
scenes.voice_over: Once baked, let the cookies cool completely before serving. Enjoy these guilt-free treats with a glass of almond milk. These macadamia butter chocolate chip cookies have about 150-200 calories, 5-7 grams of protein, 10-15 grams of carbs, and 12-15 grams of fat per serving.

cooking_tips: For chewier cookies, underbake slightly. For crispier cookies, bake for a minute or two longer.
If the dough is too sticky, chill it in the refrigerator for 15-20 minutes before shaping.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days.

recipes.name: Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease a baking sheet.
Step 2: In a bowl, thoroughly combine the peanut butter, sucralose sweetener, and eggs.
Step 3: Drop the mixture by rounded spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet.
Step 4: Bake for approximately 8 minutes, or until the centers appear dry.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three sugar-free peanut butter cookies on a rustic wooden board, dusted with a light sprinkle of powdered sweetener.  Use a slightly overhead, angled shot, focusing sharply on the front cookie's texture and the visible peanut butter swirls within.  Employ soft, natural light from the side to highlight the golden brown edges and create gentle shadows. A shallow depth of field blurs the background, featuring a linen napkin and a scattering of peanuts in the soft focus, evoking a warm, comforting mood.

video_script.title: Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies
video_script.description: A quick and easy recipe for delicious sugar-free peanut butter cookies.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown, sugar-free peanut butter cookies. Some cookies are broken in half to reveal the soft interior.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge your sweet tooth without the guilt! These sugar-free peanut butter cookies are quick, easy, and delicious.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients arranged neatly on a countertop: a jar of smooth natural peanut butter, a bag of granular no-calorie sucralose sweetener, and two large eggs in a carton.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: two cups of smooth natural peanut butter, two cups of granular no-calorie sucralose sweetener, and two large eggs.

scenes.image_prompt: An empty baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Preheat your oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit, or 175 degrees Celsius. Lightly grease a baking sheet.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl containing peanut butter, sucralose sweetener, and eggs.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine the peanut butter, sucralose sweetener, and eggs. Mix until everything is thoroughly combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Rounded spoonfuls of cookie dough being dropped onto the prepared baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Drop the mixture by rounded spoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet, leaving some space between each cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: The baking sheet with cookies in the oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for about 8 minutes, or until the centers appear dry.

scenes.image_prompt: A plate of freshly baked, golden-brown, sugar-free peanut butter cookies cooling on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of sugar-free peanut butter cookies with a glass of milk or a cup of coffee.
scenes.voice_over: Enjoy these delicious sugar-free peanut butter cookies with a glass of milk or a cup of coffee. Estimated nutrition information per cookie is: 100 calories, 5 grams of protein, 2 grams of carbs, and 8 grams of fat.

cooking_tips: For crispier cookies, bake for a minute or two longer.
If the dough is too sticky, chill it for 15-20 minutes before scooping.
Use a cookie scoop for uniform cookie sizes.

recipes.name: Low-Carb Chocolate Chip Cookies
ingredients: ¾ cup roasted unsalted macadamia nuts (or cashews)
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 320°F (160°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and set aside.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of several low-carb chocolate chip cookies on a rustic wooden board, dusted with powdered erythritol.  Focus sharply on the front cookie, highlighting the texture of the coconut and melted chocolate chips. Use soft, diffused natural light to create warm, inviting tones.  Include a scoop of macadamia nuts and a few scattered chocolate chips in the background for added interest. Shallow depth of field, moody lighting, and a rustic background should convey a sense of comforting indulgence.

video_script.title: Low-Carb Chocolate Chip Cookies
video_script.description: Indulge your sweet tooth guilt-free with these delicious low-carb chocolate chip cookies! Made with coconut and macadamia nuts, they're perfect for keto and low-carb diets.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown low-carb chocolate chip cookies, some whole, some with a bite taken out, showcasing the texture and chocolate chips.  A glass of almond milk is next to the plate.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge your sweet cravings without the guilt! These low-carb chocolate chip cookies are chewy, delicious, and perfect for anyone following a keto or low-carb lifestyle.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients arranged neatly on a wooden table: a bag of unsweetened desiccated coconut, a bowl of coconut flour, a bowl of roasted macadamia nuts, and a measuring cup with melted coconut oil.
scenes.voice_over: Let's gather our dry ingredients: unsweetened desiccated coconut, coconut flour, and roasted macadamia nuts. You can substitute cashews if you prefer.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients arranged neatly on a wooden table: two large eggs, a bowl of sugar-free chocolate chips, a bowl of erythritol, and a bottle of vanilla extract.
scenes.voice_over: For our wet ingredients, we'll need two large eggs, sugar-free chocolate chips, erythritol, and vanilla extract.

scenes.image_prompt: An oven with the temperature set to 320°F (160°C) and a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
scenes.voice_over: Preheat your oven to 320 degrees Fahrenheit (160 degrees Celsius). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with the dry ingredients being combined.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine the desiccated coconut, coconut flour, and chopped macadamia nuts.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with the wet ingredients being whisked together.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, whisk together the melted coconut oil, eggs, erythritol, and vanilla extract.

scenes.image_prompt: The wet ingredients being added to the dry ingredients and mixed together.
scenes.voice_over: Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Be careful not to overmix.

scenes.image_prompt: Scooping cookie dough onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
scenes.voice_over: Drop rounded tablespoons of cookie dough onto the prepared baking sheet, leaving some space between each cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: Cookies baking in the oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked low-carb chocolate chip cookies cooling on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of low-carb chocolate chip cookies with a glass of almond milk and a cup of coffee, garnished with a sprig of mint.
scenes.voice_over: These cookies are delicious on their own, or enjoy them with a glass of almond milk or a cup of coffee.  With only 150 calories, 3g of protein, 5g of carbs, and 14g of fat per serving, you can enjoy these guilt-free!

cooking_tips: If the dough is too crumbly, add a teaspoon of water at a time until it comes together.
For chewier cookies, underbake slightly.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days or freeze for longer storage.

recipes.name: Gluten-Free Quinoa Oatmeal Cookies
ingredients: 1 cup gluten-free old-fashioned rolled oats (not quick-cooking)
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Step 2: In a large bowl, whisk together the margarine, vanilla extract, egg, and Splenda until well combined.
Step 3: Add the oats, quinoa, and baking mix to the wet ingredients and stir until just combined. Fold in the chocolate chips.
Step 4: Drop rounded tablespoons of cookie dough onto the prepared baking sheet, leaving some space between each cookie.
Step 5: Bake for 15 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden brown.
Step 6: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely. Store in an airtight container once cooled.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of several gluten-free quinoa oatmeal cookies on a rustic wooden board. Style them with a scoop of vanilla ice cream melting slightly atop one cookie and a scattering of chocolate chips around. Use soft, natural light to highlight the cookie's texture and golden-brown color.  Maintain a shallow depth of field, focusing on the cookie with the ice cream. The mood should be warm, inviting, and comforting. The background should be a neutral, slightly blurred texture like linen or burlap.

video_script.title: Gluten-Free Quinoa Oatmeal Cookies
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and healthy gluten-free quinoa oatmeal cookies with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.voice_over: Looking for a healthy and delicious cookie? These gluten-free quinoa oatmeal cookies are packed with protein and fiber, and they're super easy to make!

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients laid out on a table: softened margarine, an egg, vanilla extract, Splenda, oats, cooked quinoa, gluten-free baking mix, and mini chocolate chips.  Focus should be on the ingredients themselves, clearly labeled if possible.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: softened margarine, vanilla extract, an egg, Splenda, gluten-free rolled oats, cooked quinoa, gluten-free baking mix, and mini chocolate chips.

scenes.image_prompt: A large bowl with the wet ingredients being whisked together: margarine, vanilla extract, egg, and Splenda. The whisk should be visible in the bowl, actively mixing the ingredients.
scenes.voice_over: In a large bowl, whisk together the margarine, vanilla extract, egg, and Splenda until light and fluffy.

scenes.image_prompt: The dry ingredients (oats, quinoa, and baking mix) being added to the wet ingredients in the bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Add the oats, quinoa, and gluten-free baking mix to the wet ingredients. Stir until just combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Folding in the chocolate chips into the cookie dough mixture in the bowl. Hand using a spatula to gently fold.
scenes.voice_over: Gently fold in the mini chocolate chips.

scenes.image_prompt: Rounded tablespoons of cookie dough being dropped onto a parchment-lined baking sheet. Emphasize the spacing between the cookies.
scenes.voice_over: Drop rounded tablespoons of cookie dough onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Leave some space between each cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: The cookies baking in the preheated oven. Show the inside of the oven with the cookies on the baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Bake in a preheated oven at 350 degrees Fahrenheit (175 degrees Celsius) for 15 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: The baked cookies cooling on a wire rack.  Some cookies can be stacked, some single, to add visual interest.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the finished cookies on a plate, perhaps with a glass of milk, or arranged artfully.  Highlight the texture and color of the final product.
scenes.voice_over: These cookies are delicious on their own or with a glass of milk. Store them in an airtight container to keep them fresh. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For chewier cookies, slightly underbake them.
If the dough is too sticky, add a tablespoon or two of additional gluten-free baking mix.
Use certified gluten-free oats and baking mix to ensure the recipe remains gluten-free.
Customize the recipe by adding other mix-ins like nuts, dried fruit, or seeds.

recipes.name: Almond Butter Brownie Cookies
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 175°C (350°F).
Step 2: In a bowl, combine the almond butter, cocoa powder, granulated sweetener, and egg. Mix with a fork until well combined.

Step 3: If the mixture is crumbly, add up to 3 tablespoons of almond milk, one tablespoon at a time, until a fudgy and soft (but not runny) batter forms. The amount of almond milk needed will depend on the texture of your almond butter.
Step 4: Stir in the sugar-free chocolate chips.
Step 5: Roll the dough into balls and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Flatten each ball to about 1 cm thick and 6 cm in diameter.

Step 6: Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the tops of the cookies begin to crack. Let the cookies cool completely on the baking sheet before handling. They will be very soft when they come out of the oven but will firm up as they cool.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three almond butter brownie cookies on a rustic wooden board, dusted with cocoa powder.  Use a slightly overhead, angled shot with a shallow depth of field, focusing on the front cookie's cracked surface and melted chocolate chips. Soft, natural light from the side should highlight the rich brown hues and textures.  Garnish with a few scattered almond slivers and a small scoop of almond butter in the background. Create a warm, inviting mood with a slightly dark, muted backdrop.

video_script.title: Almond Butter Brownie Cookies - Gluten-Free & Delicious!
video_script.description: Learn how to make these easy, fudgy, and healthy almond butter brownie cookies with just a few simple ingredients!

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of several stacked almond butter brownie cookies on a wooden board, with a glass of almond milk beside them. The cookies should look slightly cracked on top and fudgy in the center.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome to the kitchen! Today, we're making fudgy, delicious, and gluten-free Almond Butter Brownie Cookies. These cookies are easy to make with simple ingredients and perfect for satisfying your sweet tooth.

scenes.image_prompt: Show all ingredients neatly arranged on a countertop. 1 cup almond butter, cocoa powder, sweetener, sugar-free chocolate chips, an egg, and almond milk.
scenes.voice_over: Here’s what you’ll need: one cup of smooth almond butter, four tablespoons of unsweetened cocoa powder, half a cup of granulated sweetener, a quarter cup of sugar-free chocolate chips, one large egg, and three tablespoons of unsweetened almond milk, if needed.

scenes.image_prompt: Show a bowl with almond butter, cocoa powder, sweetener, and an egg being mixed together using a fork.
scenes.voice_over: Preheat your oven to 175°C or 350°F. In a bowl, combine the almond butter, cocoa powder, granulated sweetener, and egg. Mix with a fork until well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the dough being mixed after the almond milk is added in. Focus on the fudgy texture.
scenes.voice_over: If the mixture is crumbly, add almond milk, one tablespoon at a time, until you get a fudgy and soft, but not runny, batter.  The amount you need will depend on your almond butter’s texture.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of sugar-free chocolate chips being folded into the brownie batter.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the sugar-free chocolate chips until they're evenly distributed.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the process of rolling cookie dough into balls and placing them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
scenes.voice_over: Roll the dough into balls and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Flatten each ball to about 1 cm thick and 6 cm in diameter.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the cookies baking in the preheated oven. Include a timer overlay showing 10-12 minutes.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, or until the tops start to crack.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the baked almond butter brownie cookies cooling on the baking sheet. They should look slightly cracked on top.
scenes.voice_over: Let them cool completely on the baking sheet. They'll be soft at first but firm up as they cool.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the finished cookies arranged on a serving plate, perhaps with a scoop of ice cream or a glass of almond milk. Some cookies can be broken in half to show the fudgy interior.
scenes.voice_over: These Almond Butter Brownie Cookies are around 200 calories per serving, with 5 grams of protein, 20 grams of carbs, and 15 grams of fat. Enjoy them as a guilt-free treat any time of day! Thanks for watching!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use dark cocoa powder.
If you don't have granulated sweetener, you can use brown sugar or coconut sugar.
To make the cookies chewier, add an extra tablespoon of almond butter.
Store the cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week.

recipes.name: Sugar-Free Almond Oatmeal Cookies
ingredients: 50g low-carb brown sugar substitute (e.g., Sukrin Gold)
1 large egg, cold (or room temperature for thinner cookies)
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C) and position the rack in the middle. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Step 2: Chop the sliced almonds into oat-sized pieces using a food processor or by hand.
Step 3: In a medium bowl, whisk together the almond flour, oat fiber, beef gelatin, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt.

Step 4: In a large bowl, cream together the softened butter, low-carb brown sugar substitute, and vanilla extract until light and fluffy (approximately 1 1/2 minutes). Scrape down the sides of the bowl.
Step 5: Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and beat until just combined. Add the egg and beat until incorporated.
Step 6: Gently fold in the chopped almonds.
Step 7: Using a 2-tablespoon cookie scoop, portion the dough onto the prepared baking sheet, spacing the cookies about 2 inches apart.
Step 8: Bake for 8 minutes, then remove from the oven and gently tap the baking sheet on the counter about six times to flatten the cookies. Return to the oven and bake for another 6 minutes.
Step 9: Remove from the oven and lightly press down on each cookie with a spatula. Let cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture sugar-free almond oatmeal cookies on a rustic wooden board, styled with a linen napkin and scattered almonds. Use soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the cookie's texture and golden brown color. Focus on the front cookie, with a shallow depth of field blurring the background. Convey a warm, inviting mood with earthy tones. A slightly overhead angle should showcase the cookie's thickness and slightly cracked top. Garnish with a sprinkle of cinnamon.

video_script.title: Sugar-Free Almond Oatmeal Cookies
video_script.description: A delicious and healthy recipe for sugar-free almond oatmeal cookies that are perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown, sugar-free almond oatmeal cookies. Some cookies are broken open to reveal the soft interior.  Focus on the texture and the chopped almonds.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in a guilt-free treat! These sugar-free almond oatmeal cookies are chewy, nutty, and packed with flavor.  Perfect for those following a low-carb or keto lifestyle.

scenes.image_prompt: Display the dry ingredients: almond flour, oat fiber, beef gelatin, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt, neatly arranged in separate bowls or measuring spoons.
scenes.voice_over: Let's gather our dry ingredients. We'll need almond flour, oat fiber, beef gelatin, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt. This blend creates a perfectly textured cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: Show softened butter, brown sugar substitute, and vanilla extract in a mixing bowl, ready to be creamed together.
scenes.voice_over: For our wet ingredients, we'll cream together softened unsalted butter, a low-carb brown sugar substitute like Sukrin Gold, and vanilla extract.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of chopping sliced almonds into smaller pieces using a food processor or a knife on a cutting board.
scenes.voice_over: We'll give our sliced almonds a quick chop.  Aim for oat-sized pieces for the best texture.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the process of creaming butter and sugar substitute until light and fluffy, then adding the dry ingredients and mixing until just combined.
scenes.voice_over: Cream the butter and sugar substitute until light and fluffy.  Then, gradually add the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Don't overmix!

scenes.image_prompt: Show adding the egg to the batter and mixing until incorporated.
scenes.voice_over: Add a cold egg to the batter and mix until fully incorporated. Using a cold egg helps create a chewier cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: Show gently folding in the chopped almonds into the cookie dough.
scenes.voice_over: Gently fold in those chopped almonds.  Even distribution is key!

scenes.image_prompt: Show scooping cookie dough onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, ensuring even spacing.
scenes.voice_over: Using a 2-tablespoon cookie scoop, portion the dough onto a parchment-lined baking sheet. Space them about 2 inches apart.  Bake in a preheated oven at 350°F (175°C).

scenes.image_prompt: Baking sheet with cookies in the oven. Zoom in slightly to observe the cookies beginning to brown around the edges.
scenes.voice_over: After 8 minutes, remove the baking sheet and gently tap it on the counter several times to flatten the cookies. Return them to the oven for another 6 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Show removing the baked cookies from the oven and gently pressing down on each with a spatula.
scenes.voice_over: Once baked, lightly press down on each cookie with a spatula.  Let them cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished sugar-free almond oatmeal cookies on a wire rack and a plate, with a glass of almond milk or a cup of coffee.
scenes.voice_over: Enjoy these delicious and healthy cookies with a glass of almond milk or a cup of coffee. They are the perfect treat any time of day. Each cookie is roughly 150-200 calories with 5-7 grams of protein, carbs, and 12-15 grams of fat.

cooking_tips: For chewier cookies, underbake slightly. For crispier cookies, bake a minute or two longer.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week or freeze for longer storage.
If using a different brand of low-carb sweetener, adjust the amount according to the package directions.

recipes.name: Diabetic-Friendly Peanut Butter Cookies
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly coat a baking sheet with nonstick cooking spray or parchment paper.
Step 2: In a large bowl, combine the peanut butter, brown sugar, egg, and baking soda. Mix until well combined.
Step 3: Stir in the chopped peanuts.
Step 4: Drop the dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet. Flatten each cookie with a fork, creating a crosshatch pattern.
Step 5: Bake for 12-14 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden brown.
Step 6: Remove from oven and let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a top-down close-up of three diabetic-friendly peanut butter cookies on a rustic wooden board, sprinkled with chopped peanuts. Use soft, diffused natural light to highlight the golden-brown edges and crunchy texture. A shallow depth of field focuses sharply on the front cookie, blurring the others slightly.  Incorporate a small scoop of peanut butter and a few whole peanuts in the background. The mood should be warm, inviting, and wholesome.  Style the cookies with slight imperfections, emphasizing their homemade appeal.

video_script.title: Diabetic-Friendly Peanut Butter Cookies
video_script.description: A simple and delicious recipe for peanut butter cookies that are perfect for people with diabetes.

scenes.voice_over: Preheat your oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit, or 175 degrees Celsius.  Lightly coat a baking sheet with nonstick cooking spray or line it with parchment paper, like I'm doing here.

scenes.image_prompt: A large bowl with peanut butter, brown sugar, egg, and baking soda being mixed together with a spatula.
scenes.voice_over: In a large bowl, combine the peanut butter, brown sugar, egg, and baking soda. Mix everything together until it's well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped peanuts being stirred into the cookie dough.
scenes.voice_over: Now, gently stir in the chopped peanuts.

scenes.image_prompt: Rounded teaspoonfuls of cookie dough being dropped onto the prepared baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Drop the dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto your prepared baking sheet, leaving a little space between each cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: A fork flattening each cookie dough ball on the baking sheet, creating a crosshatch pattern.
scenes.voice_over: Flatten each cookie with a fork, creating a classic crosshatch pattern. This helps them bake evenly.

scenes.image_prompt: The baking sheet with cookies inside the preheated oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 12 to 14 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden brown. Keep a close eye on them so they don’t overbake.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked cookies cooling on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Remove the cookies from the oven and let them cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished peanut butter cookies on a plate, garnished with a few whole peanuts. A glass of milk is next to the plate.
scenes.voice_over: These diabetic-friendly peanut butter cookies are a perfect treat any time of day.  Enjoy them with a glass of milk or your favorite beverage. Each serving contains roughly 150-180 calories, with nutritional values shown below. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For crispier cookies, bake for a few minutes longer.
If the dough is too sticky, chill it in the refrigerator for 30 minutes before shaping.
Use a cookie scoop for uniform cookie sizes.

recipes.name: Fudgy Chocolate Chip Cookies
directions: 1. Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease baking sheets with cooking spray.
2. In a small bowl, whisk together the flour and baking soda. Set aside.
3. In a medium saucepan, melt the margarine over medium-low heat. Remove from heat and stir in the Splenda sugar baking blend, cocoa powder, brown sugar Splenda, milk, and vanilla extract.
4. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and stir until just combined.
5. Transfer the dough to a bowl, cover, and chill for 15 minutes.
6. Stir in the sugar-free chocolate chips.
7. Drop the chilled dough by rounded tablespoons onto the prepared baking sheets.
8. Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are set.
9. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three fudgy chocolate chip cookies, slightly askew, on a rustic wooden board dusted with powdered sugar.  Use a shallow depth of field, focusing sharply on the center cookie's gooey chocolate chips.  Soft, directional light from the left should highlight the cracks and textures. Incorporate a scoop of vanilla ice cream melting slightly atop the cookies and a scattering of chocolate chips around the base.  The mood should be warm, inviting, and decadent. A dark, slightly moody background will enhance the richness of the cookies.

video_script.title: Fudgy Chocolate Chip Cookies (Sugar-Free)
video_script.description: Indulge your sweet tooth with these guilt-free fudgy chocolate chip cookies! Made with Splenda, they're perfect for a low-sugar treat.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of several perfectly baked, fudgy chocolate chip cookies on a wire rack. Some cookies have a bite taken out of them to show the soft, gooey interior. Focus on the rich, dark color and the melty chocolate chips.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in rich, fudgy chocolate chip cookies without the sugar crash! These cookies are made with Splenda, so they're perfect for a guilt-free treat.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients arranged neatly on a countertop: all-purpose flour, baking soda, Splenda sugar baking blend, packed brown sugar Splenda, unsweetened cocoa powder, sugar-free chocolate chips.  Focus on the ingredients.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: all-purpose flour, baking soda, Splenda sugar baking blend, unsweetened cocoa powder, packed brown sugar Splenda, margarine, fat-free milk, vanilla extract, and sugar-free chocolate chips.

scenes.image_prompt: Margarine melting in a saucepan on a stovetop over medium-low heat.
scenes.voice_over: Start by melting the margarine in a saucepan over medium-low heat.

scenes.image_prompt: Whisking dry ingredients (flour and baking soda) together in a bowl.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour and baking soda.

scenes.image_prompt: The melted margarine in the saucepan, off the heat, with Splenda sugar baking blend, cocoa powder, brown sugar Splenda, milk, and vanilla extract being stirred in.
scenes.voice_over: Remove the melted margarine from the heat.  Stir in the Splenda sugar baking blend, cocoa powder, brown sugar Splenda, milk, and vanilla extract until well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Adding the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mixing them together with a spatula until just combined.
scenes.voice_over: Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until just combined. Don't overmix!

scenes.image_prompt: Covering the dough in a bowl with plastic wrap and placing it in the refrigerator.
scenes.voice_over: Cover the dough and chill for 15 minutes. This will prevent the cookies from spreading too much while baking.

scenes.image_prompt: Stirring the sugar-free chocolate chips into the chilled cookie dough.
scenes.voice_over: Now, gently fold in those sugar-free chocolate chips!

scenes.image_prompt: Scooping rounded tablespoons of cookie dough onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
scenes.voice_over: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Drop rounded tablespoons of dough onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or lightly greased with cooking spray.

scenes.image_prompt: Cookies baking in the preheated oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are set.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked cookies cooling on a wire rack. A glass of milk is placed next to the rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack. Enjoy them warm with a glass of milk!

cooking_tips: For extra fudgy cookies, slightly underbake them.
If using regular chocolate chips, reduce the amount of Splenda to avoid excessive sweetness.
Store cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week.

recipes.name: Sugar-Free Sugar Cookies
ingredients: 1 cup Splenda No Calorie Granulated Sweetener
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease a cookie sheet and set aside.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of several sugar-free sugar cookies on a rustic wooden board, dusted with powdered Splenda. Use soft, natural light from the side to highlight their delicate texture and golden edges.  A shallow depth of field focuses on the front cookie, revealing subtle cracks and a slightly crisp edge. Include a small scoop and a glass of unsweetened almond milk in the background, blurred for a lifestyle feel. The mood should be light, airy, and inviting, emphasizing the guilt-free indulgence of these cookies.  Garnish with a sprig of fresh mint for a pop of color.

video_script.title: Sugar-Free Sugar Cookies
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious sugar-free sugar cookies that are perfect for any occasion!

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of perfectly baked, golden-brown sugar-free sugar cookies. Some cookies are decorated with icing and sprinkles, others are plain.  A glass of milk is next to the plate.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in a guilt-free treat! Today, we're making delicious sugar-free sugar cookies that taste just like the classic recipe. They're perfect for holidays, parties, or a simple afternoon snack.

scenes.image_prompt: Display of the dry ingredients neatly arranged: all-purpose flour, cake flour, salt, and baking powder.
scenes.voice_over: Let's gather our dry ingredients: 1 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour, 1 1/2 cups of cake flour, 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and 1 teaspoon of baking powder.

scenes.image_prompt: The softened butters, Splenda, vanilla extract, egg substitute, water, and vinegar are arranged attractively.
scenes.voice_over: Now for the wet ingredients: 3/4 cup softened unsalted butter, 1/4 cup softened light butter, 1 cup of Splenda, 1 tablespoon of vanilla extract, 1/4 cup egg substitute, 1/4 cup water, and 3/4 teaspoon of white or cider vinegar.

scenes.image_prompt: Creaming together the butter and Splenda in a mixing bowl with an electric mixer.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, cream together the softened butters and Splenda until light and fluffy.

scenes.image_prompt: Adding the wet ingredients (vanilla extract, egg substitute, water, vinegar) to the creamed butter and Splenda mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Beat in the vanilla extract, egg substitute, water, and vinegar until well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Gradually adding the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mixing with an electric mixer until just combined.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing on low speed until just combined. Be careful not to overmix.

scenes.image_prompt: Rolling out the dough on a lightly floured surface.
scenes.voice_over: Lightly flour a surface and roll out the dough to about 1/4 inch thickness.

scenes.image_prompt: Cutting out cookie shapes from the rolled-out dough using cookie cutters.
scenes.voice_over: Use your favorite cookie cutters to cut out shapes and place them on the prepared baking sheet.

scenes.image_prompt: Sugar-free sugar cookies baking in a preheated oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake in a preheated oven at 350°F (175°C) for 8-10 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the finished sugar-free sugar cookies on a cooling rack, some decorated with icing and sprinkles.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely. Once cooled, decorate as desired with sugar-free icing and sprinkles.

scenes.image_prompt: A plate of the finished sugar-free sugar cookies with a variety of toppings. A glass of milk or a cup of coffee is next to the plate.
scenes.voice_over: These sugar-free sugar cookies are a delightful treat any time of day. Enjoy them with a glass of milk or a cup of coffee.  Each cookie is approximately 100 calories, 1g of protein, 20g of carbs, and 5g of fat.  Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For crispier cookies, bake for a few minutes longer.
For softer cookies, reduce baking time slightly.
Chill the dough thoroughly for easier rolling and cutting.
Use parchment paper instead of greasing the cookie sheet to prevent sticking.
Decorate the cooled cookies with sugar-free frosting or sprinkles.

recipes.name: Almond Flour Cookies with Walnuts
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.
Step 2: In a medium bowl, whisk together the almond flour, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
Step 3: In a stand mixer bowl, cream together the softened butter and sugar blend on medium-high speed for about 4 minutes, until light and fluffy.
Step 4: Beat in the egg and vanilla extract for about 2 minutes, until well combined.
Step 5: Reduce the mixer speed to low and add the chopped walnuts. Mix for about 1 minute, until evenly distributed.
Step 6: Using a mini spring-loaded ice cream scoop or a teaspoon, drop dough balls onto the prepared baking sheet, leaving about 2 inches between each cookie.
Step 7: Flatten each dough ball slightly with a fork, creating a criss-cross pattern.
Step 8: Bake for 14-15 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown. For crispier cookies, bake for an additional minute.
Step 9: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 10 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three almond flour cookies with walnuts, the top one broken open revealing its soft interior.  Use soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the cookie's texture and golden-brown color.  Style on a rustic wooden board with scattered walnuts and a linen napkin.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the broken cookie edge.  Warm, inviting mood with earthy tones.  Incorporate negative space for a clean, minimalist feel.  A sprinkling of powdered monk fruit/erythritol sweetener on the board adds a touch of elegance.

video_script.title: Almond Flour Walnut Cookies - Gluten-Free & Delicious!
video_script.description: Learn how to make these healthy, gluten-free almond flour cookies with crunchy walnuts. Perfect for a guilt-free treat!

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown almond flour cookies with chopped walnuts, some whole, some broken, next to a glass of milk on a wooden table. Soft lighting, rustic background.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today we are baking delicious and healthy almond flour cookies with crunchy walnuts. These gluten-free delights are perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients are grouped together; dry ingredients (almond flour, baking soda, salt) are in one bowl, and wet ingredients (butter, sugar, egg, and vanilla) are separated. Walnuts are in a separate small bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what we'll need: almond flour, baking soda, salt, softened butter, a monk fruit/erythritol sugar blend, an egg, vanilla extract, and chopped walnuts.

scenes.image_prompt: Whisk together almond flour, baking soda, and salt in a bowl. Focus on combining dry ingredients.
scenes.voice_over: In a medium bowl, whisk together the almond flour, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.

scenes.image_prompt: Creaming together butter and sugar blend in stand mixer. Show light and fluffy texture of mixture.
scenes.voice_over: In a stand mixer, cream together the softened butter and sugar blend on medium-high speed for about 4 minutes, until light and fluffy.

scenes.image_prompt: Beating egg and vanilla extract into the butter-sugar mixture in stand mixer.
scenes.voice_over: Beat in the egg and vanilla extract for about 2 minutes, until well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Adding chopped walnuts to wet ingredients at low speed in stand mixer.
scenes.voice_over: Reduce the mixer speed to low and add the chopped walnuts. Mix for about 1 minute, until evenly distributed.

scenes.image_prompt: Scooping cookie dough balls onto the baking sheet lined with parchment paper using a mini ice cream scoop.
scenes.voice_over: Using a mini spring-loaded ice cream scoop or a teaspoon, drop dough balls onto the prepared baking sheet, leaving about 2 inches between each cookie.

scenes.image_prompt: Flattening dough balls on a baking sheet with a fork.
scenes.voice_over: Flatten each dough ball slightly with a fork, creating a criss-cross pattern.

scenes.image_prompt: Cookies baking in a preheated oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 14-15 minutes in a preheated oven at 350°F (175°C), or until the edges are golden brown. For crispier cookies, bake for an additional minute.

scenes.image_prompt: Cooling cookies on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 10 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the final baked almond flour walnut cookies arranged on a plate with a cup of coffee.  Rustic, warm background.
scenes.voice_over: These healthy and delicious cookies are perfect with a cup of coffee or tea. Each serving has approximately 150 calories, 3 grams of protein, 5 grams of carbs and 14 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: If you don't have a spring-loaded ice cream scoop, use a tablespoon or two teaspoons to measure even portions.
Don't overmix the dough, as this can result in tough cookies.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week.

recipes.name: Diabetic-Friendly Chocolate Chip Cookies
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 300°F.
Step 2: In a small bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Step 3: In a large mixer bowl, cream together the softened butter, Splenda, agave sweetener, and vanilla extract until light and fluffy.
Step 4: Beat in the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each addition.
Step 5: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined.
Step 6: Stir in the chocolate chips and nuts (if using).
Step 7: Drop by rounded tablespoons onto ungreased baking sheets.
Step 8: Bake for 18-20 minutes, or until golden brown.
Step 9: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes before transferring them to wire racks to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of several diabetic-friendly chocolate chip cookies on a rustic wooden board, dusted with powdered Splenda.  Use soft, natural light from the side to highlight the cookie's texture and golden-brown color.  A shallow depth of field focuses sharply on the front cookies, blurring the background of scattered chocolate chips and a glass of almond milk.  Convey a warm, comforting, and inviting mood.  Garnish with a sprig of fresh mint for a touch of freshness.

video_script.title: Diabetic-Friendly Chocolate Chip Cookies
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious, guilt-free chocolate chip cookies perfect for those watching their sugar intake.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of several perfectly golden brown diabetic-friendly chocolate chip cookies on a wire rack, with a few more cookies on a baking sheet in the background.  Focus on the texture and the melted chocolate chips.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in your cookie cravings guilt-free with these diabetic-friendly chocolate chip cookies.  They're soft, chewy, and perfectly sweet, without the sugar crash.

scenes.image_prompt: Display of the dry ingredients: whole wheat pastry flour, baking soda, and salt in separate bowls, arranged neatly together. A measuring cup and spoon should also be visible.
scenes.voice_over: Let's start with the dry ingredients.  You'll need whole wheat pastry flour for a healthier twist, baking soda, and a pinch of salt.

scenes.image_prompt: Show softened butter, Splenda, agave sweetener, molasses, and vanilla extract in separate containers, ready to be combined. A mixer is visible in the background.
scenes.voice_over: For the wet ingredients, we'll use softened unsalted butter, Splenda for sweetness, agave sweetener, a touch of molasses for richness, and vanilla extract for that classic cookie flavor.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the butter, Splenda, agave, molasses and vanilla being creamed together in a mixer until light and fluffy.
scenes.voice_over: Cream together the softened butter, Splenda, agave sweetener, molasses and vanilla until light and fluffy.  This creates the base for our cookie dough.

scenes.image_prompt: Show adding the eggs one at a time to the creamed butter mixture in a mixer.
scenes.voice_over: Beat in the eggs one at a time, ensuring each egg is fully incorporated before adding the next. This adds richness and helps bind the dough.

scenes.image_prompt: Show gradually adding the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mixing with the mixer until just combined.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined. Be careful not to overmix, as this can make the cookies tough.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the chocolate chips and chopped nuts being stirred into the cookie dough.
scenes.voice_over: Now for the best part: fold in the chocolate chips and nuts. I'm using semi-sweet chocolate chips and chopped walnuts, but feel free to use your favorites.

scenes.image_prompt: Show dropping rounded tablespoons of cookie dough onto ungreased baking sheets.
scenes.voice_over: Drop rounded tablespoons of cookie dough onto ungreased baking sheets, leaving enough space between each cookie for spreading.

scenes.image_prompt: Show baking the cookies in a preheated oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake in a preheated oven at 300°F for 18-20 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the baked cookies cooling on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheets for a couple of minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.  This helps them firm up.

scenes.image_prompt: Show a close-up of the finished diabetic-friendly chocolate chip cookies arranged on a plate with a glass of milk, or a cup of sugar free coffee, some berries and nuts sprinkled on top.
scenes.voice_over: These diabetic-friendly cookies are approximately 150 calories per serving with 2 grams of protein, 25 grams of carbs, and 7 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For crispier cookies, bake for a shorter time. For chewier cookies, bake for a longer time.
Store cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week.

recipes.name: Citrusy Wholemeal Currant Cookies
ingredients: 50 grams soft brown sugar (approximately 10 heaped teaspoons)
1.5-2 teaspoons stevia powder or other sweetener (equivalent to 5 heaped teaspoons of sugar)
directions: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 170°C/Gas Mark 3.
Step 2: In a large bowl, beat together the rapeseed oil, egg, brown sugar, stevia, lemon zest, and lemon juice until well combined.
Step 3: Add the wholemeal flour, mixed spice, currants, and mixed citrus peel to the wet ingredients. Mix thoroughly until a dough ball forms.
Step 4: Lightly flour a clean work surface. Turn the dough out onto the floured surface and roll it out to a thickness of 3-4mm.

Step 5: Using a 5cm fluted pastry cutter, cut out cookies from the rolled dough. Carefully place the cut-out cookies onto a lightly oiled baking tray. Re-roll any dough scraps to cut out more cookies. This recipe should yield approximately 25 cookies.

Step 6: Bake the cookies for 7-9 minutes, or until the edges begin to turn golden brown. Remove the baking tray from the oven and sprinkle the cookies with caster sugar. Transfer the cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of several citrusy wholemeal currant cookies on a rustic wooden board. Soft, directional natural light illuminates the golden-brown cookies, highlighting the texture of the currants and mixed peel.  A shallow depth of field focuses sharply on the front cookie, showcasing its crumbly texture. The background features a subtly blurred linen napkin and scattered citrus zest.  Garnish with a few sprigs of fresh rosemary and a single slice of lemon. The mood should be warm, inviting, and slightly rustic.

video_script.title: Citrusy Wholemeal Currant Cookies
video_script.description: Learn to bake these healthy and delicious citrusy wholemeal currant cookies. Perfect for a light snack or with a cup of tea!

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown, slightly chewy wholemeal currant cookies, some whole, some broken, with visible currants and bits of candied citrus peel. A glass of milk and a few slices of orange are placed next to the plate.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're baking delicious and healthy citrusy wholemeal currant cookies. These cookies are packed with flavor and perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients are arranged in groups. Group 1: Rapeseed oil, egg, brown sugar, stevia. Group 2: Lemon zest, lemon juice. Group 3: Wholemeal flour, mixed spice, currants, chopped mixed citrus peel. Group 4: Plain flour, Caster sugar.
scenes.voice_over: Here are the ingredients you'll need. We'll start with wet ingredients: rapeseed oil, egg, brown sugar, and stevia. Then, we'll add lemon zest and juice for that citrusy kick. Dry ingredients include wholemeal flour, mixed spice, currants, and mixed citrus peel. Lastly, we’ll use plain flour for rolling and caster sugar for sprinkling.

scenes.image_prompt: A large bowl with the wet ingredients being whisked together: rapeseed oil, egg, sugars, lemon zest and juice. The mixture should look light and slightly frothy.
scenes.voice_over: In a large bowl, whisk together the rapeseed oil, egg, brown sugar, stevia, lemon zest, and lemon juice until well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: The dry ingredients (wholemeal flour, mixed spice, currants, mixed citrus peel) being added to the wet ingredients in the bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add the wholemeal flour, mixed spice, currants, and mixed citrus peel to the wet ingredients. Mix everything until a dough ball forms.

scenes.image_prompt: Rolling out the dough on a lightly floured surface to a thickness of 3-4mm.
scenes.voice_over: Lightly flour your work surface. Turn the dough out and roll it to about 3-4 millimeters thick.

scenes.image_prompt: Using a fluted pastry cutter to cut out cookies from the rolled dough.
scenes.voice_over: Using a 5cm fluted cutter, cut out your cookies. Gather any scraps and re-roll to maximize your cookie yield.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of cookies placed on a baking tray, ready to go into the oven.
scenes.voice_over: Place the cookies on a lightly oiled baking tray. Bake in a preheated oven at 170°C, or Gas Mark 3, for 7-9 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked cookies being sprinkled with caster sugar.
scenes.voice_over: Once baked, sprinkle the cookies with caster sugar while they're still warm.

scenes.image_prompt: The finished cookies cooling on a wire rack, some with bite marks, showing the soft and chewy texture.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool completely on a wire rack before enjoying. These cookies are best served fresh but can be stored in an airtight container for a few days.  Each cookie has approximately 100-120 calories, 2-3g of protein, 15-20g of carbs, and 4-6g of fat.

cooking_tips: For a crispier cookie, bake for a minute or two longer.
If the dough is too sticky, add a little extra flour.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week.

recipes.name: Low-Carb Peanut Butter Cookies
ingredients: 1/2 cup Splenda or other granulated sweetener
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Step 2: In a large mixing bowl, combine the peanut butter, eggs, sweetener, vanilla extract, and salt.
Step 3: Using an electric mixer or by hand, mix until smooth.
Step 4: If using, gently fold in the chopped peanuts.
Step 5: Use a medium cookie scoop to portion dough onto the prepared baking sheet. Press the dough firmly into the scoop and release onto the sheet.
Step 6: Flatten each cookie with a fork in a crisscross pattern.
Step 7: Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until lightly golden brown.
Step 8: Let the cookies cool completely on the baking sheet before handling. They will crisp up as they cool.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three low-carb peanut butter cookies on a rustic wooden board, dusted with powdered sweetener.  Use a slightly overhead angle, focusing sharply on the front cookie's cracked surface and gently blurring the background.  Soft, natural light should highlight the golden-brown color and peanut texture.  Include a scattering of chopped peanuts around the base and a scoop of peanut butter in the background, subtly blurred.  Create a warm, inviting mood with a shallow depth of field emphasizing the cookies' textures.

video_script.title: Low-Carb Peanut Butter Cookies
video_script.description: A quick and easy recipe for delicious low-carb peanut butter cookies.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of several golden brown, perfectly textured low-carb peanut butter cookies on a cooling rack, some with bite marks, others whole.  Focus on the soft interior and slightly crispy edges.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge your sweet tooth without the guilt! These low-carb peanut butter cookies are quick, easy, and incredibly delicious.

scenes.image_prompt: Display ingredients: Jar of creamy salted peanut butter, a bowl of eggs, a bag of Splenda, a bottle of vanilla extract, a bowl of sea salt, and a bowl of chopped peanuts (optional).
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: creamy salted peanut butter, eggs, Splenda or your preferred granulated sweetener, vanilla extract, sea salt, and optionally, some chopped peanuts for added crunch.

scenes.image_prompt: An empty mixing bowl with an electric mixer next to it on a kitchen counter. The background should show a preheated oven at 350°F.
scenes.voice_over: Preheat your oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. This will prevent sticking and ensure even baking.

scenes.image_prompt: Mixing bowl with peanut butter, eggs, sweetener, vanilla extract, and salt being combined.
scenes.voice_over: In a large mixing bowl, combine the peanut butter, eggs, sweetener, vanilla extract, and salt.

scenes.image_prompt: The mixture being creamed together using an electric mixer until smooth.
scenes.voice_over: Using an electric mixer or by hand, mix until you get a smooth, even dough.

scenes.image_prompt: Gently folding in the chopped peanuts (optional).
scenes.voice_over: If using, gently fold in the chopped peanuts.

scenes.image_prompt: Scooping cookie dough onto a parchment-lined baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Use a medium cookie scoop to portion the dough evenly onto the prepared baking sheet.

scenes.image_prompt: Flattening each cookie dough ball with a fork in a criss-cross pattern.
scenes.voice_over: Flatten each cookie dough ball with a fork in a crisscross pattern.  This not only gives them the classic peanut butter cookie look, but it also helps them bake evenly.

scenes.image_prompt: Cookies baking in the oven, showing the edges turning golden brown.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked low-carb peanut butter cookies cooling on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the cookies cool completely on the baking sheet before transferring them to a cooling rack. They will crisp up as they cool. These cookies are around 150-200 calories each, with 5-7 grams of protein, 5-7 grams of carbs, and 12-15 grams of fat per serving.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the finished low-carb peanut butter cookies on a plate, next to a glass of almond milk.
scenes.voice_over: Enjoy these delicious low-carb peanut butter cookies with a glass of almond milk or your favorite low-carb beverage.

cooking_tips: For chewier cookies, slightly underbake them.
If the dough is too sticky, refrigerate it for 15-20 minutes before scooping.
Add a pinch of cinnamon or nutmeg to the dough for a warm, spiced flavor.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week.

recipes.name: Diabetic Coconut Macaroons
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Grease a baking sheet.
Step 2: In a small bowl, combine the shredded coconut, flour, and salt.
Step 3: In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites until stiff peaks form. Gently fold in the vanilla extract.
Step 4: Carefully fold the egg white mixture into the dry ingredients until just combined.
Step 5: Drop the batter by rounded teaspoonfuls onto the prepared baking sheet.
Step 6: Bake for 18-20 minutes, or until the macaroons are lightly golden brown.
Step 7: Remove the baking sheet from the oven and let the macaroons cool completely on a wire rack.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a cluster of golden-brown diabetic coconut macaroons on a rustic wooden board, sprinkled with a dusting of powdered sugar. Use a slightly overhead angle with a shallow depth of field, focusing on the front macaroons and letting the back ones gently blur. Employ soft, diffused natural light to accentuate the texture and highlight the toasted coconut flakes. A linen napkin and a small scoop can be subtly placed in the background. The mood should be warm, inviting, and slightly rustic.

video_script.title: Diabetic Coconut Macaroons
video_script.description: A simple and delicious recipe for diabetic-friendly coconut macaroons.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown coconut macaroons, some with a bite taken out to showcase the chewy texture.  In the background, a cup of tea or coffee suggests a pairing option.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in a guilt-free treat with these delicious and diabetic-friendly coconut macaroons.  They're easy to make and perfect with a cup of tea or coffee.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of the ingredients neatly arranged on a table: shredded coconut in a bowl, flour and salt in a small dish, egg whites in a glass bowl, and vanilla extract in a small bottle.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: shredded coconut, a touch of all-purpose flour and salt, egg whites, and a dash of vanilla extract.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of whisking egg whites in a bowl until stiff peaks form.
scenes.voice_over: First, whisk the egg whites until stiff peaks form. This will give our macaroons a light and airy texture.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl with shredded coconut, flour, and salt being mixed together.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, combine the shredded coconut, flour, and salt.

scenes.image_prompt: Gently folding the whipped egg whites into the dry ingredients.
scenes.voice_over: Now, gently fold the egg white mixture into the dry ingredients until just combined. Be careful not to overmix.

scenes.image_prompt: Scooping the batter onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
scenes.voice_over: Drop the batter by rounded teaspoonfuls onto a greased baking sheet.

scenes.image_prompt: Golden brown macaroons baking in a preheated oven.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 18-20 minutes at 325 degrees Fahrenheit, or until lightly golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked macaroons cooling on a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Let the macaroons cool completely on a wire rack before serving.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished macaroons on a plate, garnished with a sprig of mint and a cup of coffee in the background.
scenes.voice_over: Each macaroon has about 70 calories, 2 grams of protein, 5 grams of carbs, and 5 grams of fat, making them a perfect diabetic-friendly treat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: If you want to add a touch of sweetness, you can add a sugar substitute like stevia or erythritol to the batter. Start with a small amount and adjust to your liking.
For chewier macaroons, reduce the baking time by a few minutes. For crispier macaroons, bake for the full 20 minutes.

recipes.name: Oatmeal Orange Cookies
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
Step 2: In a medium mixing bowl, cream together the softened butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy.
Step 3: Beat in the egg white and applesauce until just combined.
Step 4: In a separate bowl, whisk together the whole wheat pastry flour, rolled oats, wheat bran, baking soda, cream of tartar, and cinnamon.
Step 5: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined. Stir in the orange zest and juice.
Step 6: Drop rounded tablespoons of dough onto the prepared baking sheets, leaving about 2 inches between each cookie.
Step 7: Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.
Step 8: Remove from oven and let cool on the baking sheets for a few minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three Oatmeal Orange Cookies, slightly askew, on a rustic wooden board dusted with powdered sugar.  A single cookie, broken in half revealing its chewy texture, rests in the foreground. Backdrop a textured linen napkin in a warm, neutral tone.  Utilize soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the golden-brown hues and oat texture. Shallow depth of field, focusing on the broken cookie, with a bright, inviting mood. Garnish with a few orange zest curls.

video_script.title: Oatmeal Orange Cookies
video_script.description: A delicious and healthy cookie recipe packed with flavor and wholesome ingredients.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown oatmeal orange cookies. Some cookies are broken open to reveal a soft, chewy interior. The background is slightly blurred, with a hint of orange zest.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're baking these delicious and healthy oatmeal orange cookies, perfect for a guilt-free treat. They're packed with oats, whole wheat, and a burst of citrusy orange flavor.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients are arranged on a wooden table. Grouped items include: Butter, both sugars, and egg white in one group. Applesauce, flour, oats, wheat bran, baking soda, cream of tartar, and cinnamon are in a second group. Finally, Orange zest and juice are grouped together.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need. For the wet ingredients: softened butter, granulated sugar, brown sugar, an egg white, and unsweetened applesauce. For the dry ingredients: whole wheat pastry flour, rolled oats, wheat bran, baking soda, cream of tartar, and cinnamon. And for that citrusy kick: the zest and juice of one orange.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with softened butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar. A hand uses an electric mixer to cream the ingredients.
scenes.voice_over: In a medium bowl, cream together the softened butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy.

scenes.image_prompt: The same bowl, now with the creamed butter and sugar mixture. A hand is adding an egg white and unsweetened applesauce to the bowl and mixes them in.
scenes.voice_over: Beat in the egg white and applesauce until just combined.

scenes.image_prompt: A separate bowl containing whole wheat pastry flour, rolled oats, wheat bran, baking soda, cream of tartar, and ground cinnamon being whisked together.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, whisk together the dry ingredients: flour, oats, bran, baking soda, cream of tartar, and cinnamon.

scenes.image_prompt: The wet ingredients are being combined with the dry ingredients. A spatula folds the two mixtures together.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined. Don't overmix.

scenes.image_prompt: Orange zest and orange juice are being added to the cookie dough and incorporated into the batter.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the orange zest and orange juice.

scenes.image_prompt: Rounded tablespoons of cookie dough are being dropped onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. The cookies are spaced apart from each other.
scenes.voice_over: Drop rounded tablespoons of dough onto prepared baking sheets, leaving about 2 inches between each cookie. Preheat oven to 350°F.

scenes.image_prompt: The cookies are baking in the oven, and the edges are turning golden brown.
scenes.voice_over: Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.

scenes.image_prompt: Freshly baked oatmeal orange cookies cooling on a wire rack. A glass of milk is placed next to the rack.
scenes.voice_over: Remove from oven and let cool on the baking sheets for a few minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. Enjoy these healthy cookies with a glass of milk.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a finished oatmeal orange cookies with a glass of milk, ready to be enjoyed. Text overlay displaying nutritional information per serving: Calories 150, protein 2g, carbs 25g, fat 6g
scenes.voice_over: Each cookie has approximately 150 calories, 2 grams of protein, 25 grams of carbs, and 6 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For chewier cookies, use less flour. For crispier cookies, use more flour.
If the dough is too sticky, chill it in the refrigerator for 30 minutes before baking.
Add 1/2 cup of chopped nuts or chocolate chips to the dough for extra flavor and texture.
